abstract: It may not be popular to say, but the incontrovertible fact remains that JPMorgan Chase has remained one of the best-performing banks on Wall Street under Jamie Dimon.
snippet: It may not be popular to say, but the incontrovertible fact remains that JPMorgan Chase has remained one of the best-performing banks on Wall Street under Jamie Dimon.
lead_paragraph: “This isn’t about good governance; it’s about busybodies without a clue, trying to do the dumbest thing — slapping and shaming a superb C.E.O. for utterly no practical reason.”

headline.main: Making a Case for One Leader at JPMorgan
headline.print_headline: Making a Case For One Leader At JPMorgan

abstract: Daniel S. Loeb has called for a breakup of Sony. | The debate over a shareholder vote at JPMorgan Chase seems to be about semantics, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes. | Bloomberg L.P. is scrambling to appease nervous customers. | Cantab Capital Partners has a new fund that aggressively undercuts its competitors on fees.
snippet: Daniel S. Loeb has called for a breakup of Sony. | The debate over a shareholder vote at JPMorgan Chase seems to be about semantics, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes. | Bloomberg L.P. is scrambling to appease nervous customers. | Cantab Capital Partners ...
lead_paragraph: Daniel S. Loeb, an American hedge fund billionaire known for starting big fights, has called for a breakup of the entertainment and electronics giant Sony, possibly setting off a battle that could roil Japan’s staid corporate culture, Andrew Ross Sorkin and Michael J. de la Merced report in DealBook. “The call, which came on Tuesday, will most likely be viewed by government officials and corporate leaders in Tokyo as a shot across the bow from Wall Street, just as Western investors begin piling into Japanese stocks.”

abstract: A proposal to separate the chairman and chief executive positions at JPMorgan Chase has turned into a backdoor referendum on Jamie Dimon.
snippet: A proposal to separate the chairman and chief executive positions at JPMorgan Chase has turned into a backdoor referendum on Jamie Dimon.
lead_paragraph: The fight over whether to split the jobs of chief executive and chairman at JPMorgan Chase is a silly one. That’s not just because it’s a lot of drama over something so unimportant in the scheme of things, but because it has turned into a backdoor referendum on one man, Jamie Dimon.

headline.main: Dispute at JPMorgan Grows, for All the Wrong Reasons
headline.print_headline: Dispute at JPMorgan Grows, for All the Wrong Reasons
